fileDesc.extent: Nine total calendar entries that Mary Behrend wrote and/or drew on.

publicationStmt.p: COPYRIGHT 1908, BY FRIENDSHIP CALENDAR CO. NEW BRITAIN, CONN.

msIdentifier.repository: Penn State Erie, The Behrend College Library

handDesc.handNote: Likely Mary Behrend writing in a red pen.
Likely Mary behrend writing in a black pen.
Text printed onto the page from the calendar manufacturing company.
Text that doesn't look like pen, but is not printed onto the page.

figure.fw: COPYRIGHT 1908, BY FRIENDSHIP CALENDAR CO. NEW BRITAIN, CONN.
figure.figDesc: There is a brown house covered with foliage, the roof appears to be made of a hay-like substance, and smoke is coming from the chimney. It covers most of the 1909 and the last three letters of Thursday, and there is red pen to the right of the house. Everything on this page is written in red pen.

ab.quote: Some love the glow of outward shore. Some love more & and try to it; The house to me may lowly be if I get like the people in it

figure.fw: COPYRIGHT 1908, BY FRIENDSHIP CALENDAR CO. NEW BRITAIN, CONN.
figure.figDesc: There is no drawing; only one quote, and everything is in red pen.

ab.quote: To live in hearts or leave behind, is not to die.
ab.name: Campbell

figure.fw: COPYRIGHT 1908, BY FRIENDSHIP CALENDAR CO. NEW BRITAIN, CONN.
figure.figDesc: A man lay in his bed and stares begrudgingly at his alarm clock, the light from the window bright enough to illuminate the room. The clock reads 3:30, but the man appears to have just woken up. Interestingly, there is no red text here.
figure.ab: E.R.B. That damned old clock gives me a slecle. Each . where it's dark. It likes it's fun,but I've become to tire of thee dark!

figure.head: COPYRIGHT 1908, BY FRIENDSHIP CALENDAR CO. NEW BRITAIN, CONN.
figure.figDesc: A sketch of a man outside holding a bug near a tree. Watercolor appears to have been used for this page, and there is red text at the bottom.
figure.ab: Mr. Behrend feeds a loud bug!
I wonder if you have found your way lately!

figure.fw: COPYRIGHT 1908, BY FRIENDSHIP CALENDAR CO. NEW BRITAIN, CONN.
figure.figDesc: There is no drawing here, this page consists entirely of text. There is a sentence on the bottom written in red ink, however.
figure.ab: Each morning very early where all is dark & still, early blackness to leave at Hammermill.
I really think he's very good to get up when it's dark. For this he says he doesn't mind it could be leecle a lark!
! is it still dark where you arise?

figure.fw: COPYRIGHT 1908, BY FRIENDSHIP CALENDAR CO. NEW BRITAIN, CONN.
figure.figDesc: A red question mark covers up the entire page. A small amount of text is on the bottom right of the page, written in red ink.
figure.ab: Parliafs this is it will or later. Love,

figure.fw: COPYRIGHT 1908, BY FRIENDSHIP CALENDAR CO. NEW BRITAIN, CONN.
figure.figDesc: Four women are wearing fancy dresses and feathered hats. The first woman in purple has red hair while the rest are blond. The other three women are wearing red, blue, and green respectively, with the red and green women yelling at the woman in blue. The red woman's hat covers up the U, R, and some of the S in Thursday and there is red writing on the left side.
figure.ab: Everybody dressed in their best for this is an Erie tea. They eat too much, talk too much- you can bet they won't rope in me.
I suppose she is very gay in Erie?

figure.fw: COPYRIGHT 1908, BY FRIENDSHIP CALENDAR CO. NEW BRITAIN, CONN.
figure.figDesc: A woman is wearing a pair of large snowshoes and is trying to walk in them. There is red writing in the bottom right corner.
figure.ab: Molly on snowshoes that Mr. Weir got. Pretty picture is it not?!

figure.fw: COPYRIGHT 1908, BY FRIENDSHIP CALENDAR CO. NEW BRITAIN, CONN.
figure.figDesc: There are doodles of snakes around the date, one directly below "Saint Patrick's Day" and one on the top right of the calendar. Four clovers are scattered across the page and a picture of Hammermill Paper Company is drawn at the bottom and red text below it.
figure.ab: St. Patrick was a useful saint. He frightened all the snakes away- I wish he'd try his art on smoke around the Hammermill some day!

figure.figDesc: This photo has an an envelope with Mary Behrend's calendar pages on top of it. The top page is the first calendar entry. To the right, there is a frayed book decorated with white and blue flowers with Baby Days embroidered on the cover and some loose pages underneath it.
